qas.question: During what period did people use Kermes vermilio to make red dye?
What does Kermes vermilio eat to survive?

answers.text: the sap of certain trees, especially Kermes oak trees

qas.question: From where did Romans acquire Kermes?
What kind of bural was at Adaoutse, Bouches-du-Rhône?
What was the earliest known writing about dye from Aermenian cochineal?

plausible_answers.text: by drying and then crushing the bodies of the females of a tiny scale insect

qas.question: How was Kermes made in the 8th century BC?
The insects only live on what tree in the Mediterranean?
Where have jars of Kermes been found in Adoutse caves?
Who imported Kermes oak trees from the Romans?
What was mentioed in the 8th century?

context: A red dye called Kermes was made beginning in the <a0_0>Neolithic Period<a0_0/> <b5_0>by drying and then crushing the bodies of the females of a tiny scale insect<b5_0/> in the genus Kermes, primarily Kermes vermilio. The insects live on <a1_0>the sap of certain trees, especially <b6_0>Kermes oak trees<b6_0/><a1_0/> near the Mediterranean region. Jars of kermes have been found in a <a3_0>Neolithic cave-burial<a3_0/> at Adaoutse, <b7_0>Bouches-du-Rhône<b7_0/>. Kermes from oak trees was later used by Romans, who imported it from <a2_0><b8_0>Spain<b8_0/><a2_0/>. A different variety of dye was made from <b9_0>Porphyrophora hamelii<b9_0/> (Armenian cochineal) scale insects that lived on the roots and stems of certain herbs. It was mentioned in texts as early as the <a4_0>8th century BC<a4_0/>, and it was used by the ancient Assyrians and Persians.
